BizCapital

March 2017 - December 2017

Overview

BizCapital is an online lender that wants to bridge the credit access gap for SMBs. I helped them build and improve many parts of their user experience and customer acquisition.

Role

Product Design
Product Strategy
User Experience Research
User Interface Design
Front-End Web Development (HTML & Sass using Bootstrap, Vue.js and Nuxt.js)
Content Strategy

Team

1 Product Designer
1 Software Architect
1 Back-End Engineer

Loan Management (Client)

Mobile • Web-based

Situation

We weren't in need of an application to provide to our customers since most of the friction was caused by lack of automation and bureaucratization of processes.

That was until our clients started to show us that they had a very particular need: autonomy. This would reduce not only a lot of friction for the already customers but a lot of internal work as well.

Through research, we built a list of use cases to serve as the foundation of this product and prioritized a few of them. So, the first iteration of this product made possible to our customers to keep track of their loan status and make payments without having to contact us, which was a real game changer.

Customer Loan Application

Web • Responsive

Situation

The customer acquisition is one of the most important processes inside an online lending company because it intersects Credit Analysis, Data Science, Marketing and User Experience.

It is a touchpoint that collects crucial information to make the business not only stay on the right track but also thrive in such crowded and regulated market as online lending. Also, the customer experience provided by commercial banks leaves us too many options to tackle.

What if we could translate this painful and complicated process into a web product that provides the customer constant feedback and is always being improved to reduce interaction costs so that we can maximize the information collected to nurture all areas of the business while we minimize user effort?

Our team worked on two iterations of this product. Being the first one treated as an MVP, we could learn where to reduce friction and where to focus on automation. Our second iteration achieved 25% less drop-off than the other in the first month of comparison.
